content.webTitle: Letters: Banks are failing the economy

fields.headline: Banks are failing the economy
fields.bodyText: That Germany is growing out of recession at twice the rate of the UK (Report, 14 August) is not nearly as worrying as that economies in Latin America (Brazil, Peru, Panama, Chile), and Asia (India, China, Indonesia, Thailand) have typical growth rates of between 6% and 9%. We are getting relatively poorer fast. But over the longer term, the real point is the failure of our financial services and banks to deliver growth and assure our economic wellbeing. Up to the recession in 1990, when our economy switched from manufacturing to banking services, we were accustomed to growth rates of 2%-5%. Since then anything above 1.5% is a cause for celebration. Right now, the banks are transparent that to keep the price of their commodity (money) high, they are prepared to restrict its availability (M4 has fallen by 50% since 2008), thereby placing a cap on GDP and so reducing growth – it's in their interest to do so. So, we should ask ourselves the question: is public sector cost too high – or GDP and economic growth too low? And then ask the question Michael Moore asks in his recent film: has there been a financial coup d'etat by the banks? Professor Saville Kushner University of the West of England Barry Kushner Blue Urban Sky, Liverpool • Consumer Focus says banks "need to offer affordable short-term loans" (1.2 million employees take out expensive payday loans, 14 August) – something that is unlikely to happen, given that such loans rarely bring the returns banks demand. However, credit unions, although they are not yet visible on every high street, are growing fast. My own union offers loans from £50 to £7,500, with interest rates from 10.9% to a max of 26.8%, with no hidden fees. John Richards Manager, Gateway Credit Union, Pontypool, Gwent
